text: Patient: No. Doctor: but it’s just, you know, we obsess about numbers. So, we’re like, “GAHHHH, where’d the platelets go?” And, that’s that. Appetite loss… Family Member: Ohhhh… (laughter) Doctor: Can occur which we can only pray for. Doctor: I would say that’s about it. I mean, in terms of what I really see people feeling bad about. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the fatigue, you know, for somebody like you who is on the go constantly could be significant. Like, I don’t want to minimize that in the . You have Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay.

text: Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyway. Patient: Yeah. Uh, the last time that that you saw a spot or spots on my bone, you used radiation to go with it. Doctor: Right. text: Family Member: You don't know yet if you want to do the trial. Patient: If I do the trial. I take what they give me. Family Member: Oh, that's right. Doctor: Yeah there's no choice there. Family Member: So if he wants to go somewhere, what’s the longest period of time he can be gone? Doctor: Oh. Well, probably three or four weeks Family Member: You can handle that. Doctor: Yeah, there is like a you know, plus minus, so if it’s like a special thing you know, might be five or six weeks so we can work with you guys. Because people have lives and they take vacation, they have other things they gotta do. Family Member: Right Doctor: That isn’t just cancer. Family Member: Actually I thought it was going to be worse, but you’re saying it’s every three weeks or so. I’m pretty surprised. I’m surprised. Doctor: Yeah, for standard dosing, just no trial, just once for an hour every three weeks is the infusion. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds. Doctor: Perhaps. Patient: The article mentioned about a miracle drug performing. Metforim. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I had stashed away and I should be doing this. But I started taking five hundred milligrams Metformin I meant to talk to you the last time I was here. Doctor: Now in the past we because the glucosol Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time.

text: Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that’s a reasonable study for ya, but you know, again, you would Patient: Screw a weekend, yeah. About an hour and half of life. Doctor: Um. So, that, you know, again, the vitamin C has to be given here because we’re paying for it. Patient: Right. Doctor: The other study that right now, the-the call that I got interrupted was about your eligibility for a phase one study. Uh, that is a first in human of a brand new drug that we’re evaluating only in prostate cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though?

text: Patient: Well. We would start first with the Xtandi. I have to – the disease has to progress some more – Doctor: Uh, by PSA only. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I don’t think you’re gonna need new scans, but that maybe sort of something down the road, but I think you, you really just have to have a rising PSA on the enzalutamide, and then we have to repeat that ARV seven. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay? Family Member: Is that Xtandi a, a injection or a pill or – Doctor: It’s a pill. He takes four pills a day. Family Member: Oh, alright. I get it. Doctor: Gives you fatigue, tiredness. Patient: I had two extra bottles I gave back to Family Member: And then, uh, and then he’s going to take it for awhile. And he’ll come down here and get -- in a month or how--how soon?

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Not, not that there was anything different before or after. So, uh, the two drugs, about sixty plus percent of men respond overall. So that’s what I said. About two-thirds of the guys respond, and then one-third seems to have a long response, and one-third has a shorter response, and one-third don’t. Uh, in terms of how to pick which one of those two. Uh, for a while, I, I was picking Zytiga instead of Xtandi. Zytiga, the one complication with Zytiga, is you have to take a small dose of prednisone with it, uh, to kind of counterbalance how Zytiga works. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the one reason we would do that is because we had some trials, uh, that were after Zytiga. But the other reason was a tendency of less fatigue with the Zytiga than the Xtandi, in my experience. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Both drugs can cause fatigue. But it seems to be more common and often a little bit worse with Xtandi. So, uh, in my choosing those two, I have been choosing Zytiga, just for that reason. Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug. Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium.

Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug. Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
